In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  has  asked  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) to build on the work 
of  the  prior  small-scale  technical  assistance  (SSTA)  for  Financing  Road  Construction  and 
Maintenance after Fuel Tax Reform, which was completed in 2010.1 The SSTA assessed the 
initial results of fuel tax reform and identified the key road sector financing issues that should be 
examined in more detail in this follow-up TA.  
 
2.  This report is based on the understanding reached between the government and the TA 
fact-finding mission fielded on 11–12 November 2010 in conjunction with the presentation of the 
draft final report and final workshop of the SSTA. This TA report reflects agreements reached on 
the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, costs, financing arrangements, 
and  terms  of  reference  for  consulting  services  for  the  TA.2 The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  In recent years, the combination of provincial government financing and debt, toll-based 
debt financing, and direct financial support from the national government has brought rapid 
expansion of the system of ordinary,3 national, and provincial trunk roads in the PRC. From 
1995 to 2009, the total roadway system in the PRC more than doubled, growing from 1.16 
million kilometers to 3.86 million kilometers. Additional expansion is planned for most road 
classes, but the current pace of investment will be difficult to sustain with the limited financial 
resources available to pay for system expansion and growing needs for system operation and 
maintenance.  Many  provincial  governments  with  limited  resources  have  neglected  road 
maintenance in favor of construction, which has put a significant percentage of the ordinary road 
network in substandard condition. There is growing understanding in the PRC of the need to 
focus on asset management and maintenance in addition to expanding the network and of the 
need for a road financing system that supports both of these goals. 
 
4.  In December 2008, the State Council announced the fuel tax reform to (i) encourage fuel 
efficiency,  (ii)  establish  a  stable  source  of  funds  for  road  construction  and  maintenance, 
(iii) simplify the tax structure, and (iv) link cost recovery with usage of transport infrastructure. In 
January 2009, the gasoline tax was raised from CNY0.2 to CNY1.0 per liter and the light oil tax 
from CNY0.1 to CNY0.8 per liter. At the same time, several local fees were abolished, tolls on 
new class II roads were disallowed, and tolls on existing class II roads began to be phased out. 
The PRC government also made important policy changes to the existing vehicle purchase tax 
that are expected to reduce the revenues it provides. To encourage the purchase of vehicles 
that are more efficient and less polluting, the vehicle purchase tax rate was reduced from 10% 
to 5% for passenger cars with an engine displacement of 1.6 liters and less. The tax reduction 
came into effect in January 2009.  
 
5.  The fuel tax reform initiative represents important evolution in the PRC’s approach to 
delivering its highway program. But the combination of abolished fees and annulled tolls on 
class  II  roads,  rising  construction  costs  and  maintenance  spending  needs,  and  the  rapid 
imposition and implementation of the fuel tax reform leave several uncertainties about the

sustainability  of  the  PRC’s  road  programs.  The  deterioration  of  existing  ordinary  roads  is 
increasingly apparent, particularly in rural areas and poorer provinces. Helping the PRC to 
devise a road financing system that ensures adequate maintenance of existing roads, provides 
a stable funding source for ordinary road construction, and supports the PRC’s policies of 
directing additional resources to poorer provinces, would support inclusive growth by reducing 
transport costs and improving transport conditions.  
 
6.  The  SSTA  began  implementation  in  2009  and  was  completed  in  December  2010, 
serving as the basis for this follow-up TA. The SSTA found that reform has realized many of its 
goals and principles, including (i) a more equitable tax burden and normalization of fees more 
aligned with the principle of the user pays, (ii) improved tax collection efficiency, (iii) enhanced 
central government planning and policy influence, and (iv) stronger incentive to reduce fuel 
consumption and achieve energy savings and emission reductions. 
 
7.  On  the  other  hand,  the  SSTA  study  findings  highlighted  several  key  policy  issues 
associated with the PRC’s current highway programs and financing system that need to be 
addressed to help ensure the long-term sustainability of the financing system for ordinary roads:  
(i)  Declining purchasing power. Because the current fuel tax is a fixed excise tax 
at a set rate per volume, inflation immediately begins to erode the purchasing 
power of tax revenues. It is unclear whether or not revenues from the current 
vehicle purchase tax will keep up with inflation.   
(ii)  Inadequate funding. The analysis of construction and maintenance needs and 
revenues for ordinary roads reveals that, under the current financing approach, 
the PRC likely faces a large funding gap that has tended to leave maintenance 
funding inadequate in the past. While there are uncertainties, the findings make it 
clear that substantial increases above current road funding levels are needed for 
the PRC to properly maintain and continue developing its roads. 
(iii)  Future use of debt by provincial and local governments. The government 
should ensure that debt will be used in a productive, responsible, and sustainable 
fashion. 
(iv)  Longer-term funding considerations. Although the short-term prospects for the 
fuel  tax  are  strong,  the  transition  to  electric  and  high-efficiency  vehicles  will 
eventually reduce fuel consumption and limit the sustainability of using the fuel 
tax as the primary mechanism for financing ordinary roads. Several developed 
countries have begun to take this possibility seriously and have determined that 
distance-based taxes will one day need to supplement or replace fuel taxes. The 
PRC may wish to explore whether a distance-based tax is a future option and, if 
so,  consider  the  steps  needed  in  the  next  few  years  to  facilitate  a  smooth 
transition. 
(v)  Program administration and performance. A major benefit of centralizing the 
collection of road charges and the allocation of road funding is that it provides the 
central  government  with  justification  and  means  to  ensure  limited  roadway 
resources are spent efficiently, effectively, and in accordance with national goals 
and priorities. To date, however, the bulk of the fuel tax reform has focused on 
imposing the new tax and allocating the funding; limited thought has been given 
to  how  roles  and  responsibilities  for  the  roadway  program  should  evolve  to 
support more sustainable programs.

3
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
8.  The TA will help the government to develop a sustainable and equitable funding system 
for road maintenance and ordinary road development in the PRC. It will address the issues 
identified under the SSTA as the key barriers to developing a sustainable road financing system. 
These barriers are (i) insufficient resources available for required maintenance and planned 
construction and (ii) deficiencies in program administration, management, and performance. 
The  TA  will  develop  specific  policy  recommendations  and  an  implementation  strategy  to 
address these barriers, which the Ministry of Transport (MOT) can use to build consensus 
among  key  government  agencies  and,  eventually,  propose  to  the  State  Council.  The  TA 
implementation  strategy  and  plan  will  propose  a  testing  and  phasing-in  period  for  the 
recommended policy and programmatic changes. The government may select one or more pilot 
provinces in which to test and demonstrate the viability and effectiveness of the proposed 
reforms and provide models that can be scaled up countrywide. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the TA will be a sustainable financing system for ordinary roads in the 
PRC measured by (i) the improved condition of the ordinary road network and (ii) targets 
achieved for ordinary road network expansion under the Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015. 
The outcome of the TA will be policy recommendations, measures, and action plans to ensure a 
sustainable road financing system, upon which MOT and the interagency steering committee 
agree.4  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The outputs of the TA will be detailed policy proposals, reform recommendations, and 
implementation plans with two broad purposes: (i) to ensure adequate resources are available 
to  fund  needed  maintenance  and  planned  road  construction  and  (ii)  to  improve  program 
administration, management, and performance.  
 
11.  With respect to the quantity of resources, the key outputs will be (i) a recommended 
approach to ensure fuel tax revenues keep up with inflation, (ii) feasible new revenue sources 
proposed to close the funding gap, (iii) clarification of the role of debt financing for roads and 
recommendations  for  proper  regulations  and  oversight  responsibilities  with  respect  to  debt 
usage, and (iv) an assessment of the feasibility of fuel taxes in the long term and recommended 
steps to be taken in the next few years to facilitate a smooth transition to an alternative tax in 
the medium- to long-term.  
 
12.  With respect to program administration, management, and performance, the key outputs 
will  be  (i)  recommendations  for  the  appropriate  roles  and  responsibilities  regarding  road 
planning,  financing,  management,  and  system  performance  at  each  level  of  government; 
(ii) recommendations on whether to move to a programmatic approach, in which funding would 
be dedicated to specific purposes aligned with national priorities that may include ensuring road 
maintenance is carried out, promoting environmental goals, ensuring that development priorities 
for  western  provinces  are  accounted  for,  and  improved  road  safety,  among  others; 
(iii) recommended  changes  to  fund  management  and  allocation  formulas  to  ensure 
transparency and accountability and provide an effective financing platform for less-developed 
western provinces; (iv) an assessment of the organizational capacity of central government

agencies  to  effectively  oversee  and  manage  a  centralized  roadway  funding  program;  and 
(v) recommended performance targets to be established for different elements of the roadway 
system (e.g., congestion, pavement condition, bridge condition, safety), program administration 
(e.g., administrative costs, on-time and on-budget delivery, transparency and accountability), 
and investment and subsidy criteria (e.g., return on investment, distributional goals, regional 
equity). 
 
13.  Knowledge products and services. Additional knowledge products and services that 
build on the findings of the TA will be developed to provide information to key policy makers in 
the  PRC  and  in  other  developing  member  countries.  At  the  conclusion  of  the  study,  the 
consultant team and MOT will organize a seminar to explain the findings of the TA, present the 
policy recommendations to senior policy makers, and seek broad consensus on the need for 
additional  resources  and  sector  reform.  Additional  knowledge  products  and  services  may 
include technical notes on key road finance-reform issues or the development of a component in 
the knowledge-sharing platform by which the PRC could share with other countries in the region 
its experiences in implementing and managing a financing system for road construction and 
maintenance based on fuel taxes. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $550,000 equivalent. ADB will provide $450,000 
equivalent on a grant basis from its Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
The government will finance the remaining $100,000 equivalent with in-kind contributions, which 
will include suitably furnished office accommodations with utilities; telecommunication access; 
materials,  maps,  data,  and  documents  required  by  the  TA;  and  local  transportation.  The 
government will further cover the costs of utilities for the consultants, counterpart professional 
staff, and support staff (Appendix 2). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  MOT will be the executing agency for the TA, responsible for guiding and supervising TA 
activities and for coordinating with government agencies and organizations, including provincial 
and local governments. MOT will form a project steering committee to guide and support the TA. 
This committee will be chaired by the deputy director general of the Comprehensive Planning 
Department of MOT. It will include senior officials of the Comprehensive Planning Department 
and Highway Administration Department, as well as officers of the Ministry of Finance, the 
National  Development  and  Reform  Commission,  and  other  agencies.  MOT  will  assign 
appropriate counterpart staff to assist the consultants. Tripartite meetings involving ADB, MOT, 
and the consultants will provide guidance to the consultants and review their reports. The 
consultants will submit reports to ADB and MOT as scheduled in the design and monitoring 
framework  (Appendix  1).  All  reports  from  the  consultants  will  be  provided  in  English  and 
translated into Chinese.  
 
16.  ADB will engage a team of national consultants through a consulting firm, in accordance 
with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) on the basis 
of the quality of the proposal (90%) and the cost of the services to be provided (10%), using 
simplified technical proposal procedures. The 90:10 weighting is appropriate because (i) the TA 
is  an  advanced  assignment  that  requires  a  high  degree  of  expertise  in  financing  road 
construction and maintenance and (ii) the consulting services will have a significant impact on 
the road sector, road users, and other stakeholders in the PRC. To ensure the quality of the 
international consulting services available to the TA, ADB will engage international consultants

5
individually in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. The external peer 
reviewer will likewise be engaged as an international individual consultant in accordance with 
ADB guidelines. 
 
17.  The TA will require 20 person-months of national and 7 person-months of international 
consultant inputs to satisfy the terms of reference (Appendix 3). The national consultants will 
have experience with similar assignments in the fields of (i) road sector financing, (ii) national 
transportation program administration, and (iii) tax policy and law. The international consultants 
will have experience with conducting similar assignments in the fields of road sector financing 
and transportation program administration. Disbursement will be undertaken in line with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA 
will be implemented over 10 months from March 2011 to December 2011. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Financing  Road  Construction  and 
Maintenance after Fuel Tax Reform (Phase 2), and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General

Construction and Maintenance after Fuel Tax Reform (Phase 2) will perform their tasks in close 
consultation with the Ministry of Transport (MOT), other national government agencies, and 
local governments to ensure full acceptance of the TA outcome. The TA will require 7 person-
months  of  international  consulting  services  and  20  person-months  of  national  consulting 
services over 10 months. The consultants should demonstrate extensive consulting skills and 
experience  in  the  fields  of  (i) road  sector  financing  policy  (4  person-months  international, 
6 person-months national); (ii) financial analysis and program management in the road sector 
(3 person-months  international,  5 person-months  national);  (iii)  economics  and  forecasting 
(5 person-months national); and (iv) tax policy and law in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) 
(4 person-months national). 
 
2.  The national road sector financing specialist will be the team leader. The consultant 
should have extensive knowledge and at least 10 years’ experience of road sector finance and 
policy, including in-depth appreciation of (i) the background of fuel tax reform; (ii) the roles and 
responsibilities  of  MOT,  other  key  PRC  ministries,  and  provincial  and  local  governments 
involved in road financing, construction, and maintenance; and (iii) the national, provincial, and 
local financing systems for road construction and maintenance. The consultant should have 
experience in collecting and analyzing as research financial data on road construction and 
maintenance at national, provincial, and local levels.  
 
3.  The  national  financial  analysis  and  program  management  specialist  should  have 
extensive knowledge and at least 8 years’ experience of road sector planning and development 
and the financial analysis of road projects and programs. The consultant should also have 
knowledge  and  practical  experience  of  the  administration  and  management  of  national, 
provincial, and local road financing systems and programs and in-depth appreciation of (i) road 
infrastructure policy in the PRC; (ii) the administration of funding programs for road maintenance 
and  construction  in  the  PRC  after  fuel  tax  reform;  and  (iii)  issues  related  to  financial 
management, system performance, and data availability in the road sector at the national, 
provincial, and local levels.  
 
4.  The national economics and forecasting expert will have extensive knowledge of and at 
least 10 years’ experience with developing tax revenue forecasts in the PRC. He or she will be 
familiar with the data that is available from national and provincial governments that will be 
required to estimate future tax revenues. The consultant will be responsible for documenting the 
revenue-forecasting methodology and all assumptions, ensuring that all the needed data is 
collected, and preparing estimates of the revenues that could be raised from each potential 
revenue source. 
 
5.  The national tax policy and legal advisor should have extensive knowledge and at least 
8 years’ experience with fuel tax reform, including an appreciation of (i) tax policy, mechanisms, 
and implementation; (ii) fuel tax revenues and revenue-allocation systems; and (iii) the national 
and provincial legal frameworks in the PRC for tax policy reform, tax system management, and 
tax policy implementation. 
 
6.  The international road sector financing specialist will be the deputy team leader. The 
consultant should have extensive knowledge and at least 10 years’ experience of road sector

B.  Scope of Work 
 
8.  The basis for the work under this TA is the prior small-scale TA (SSTA) Financing Road 
Construction and Maintenance after Fuel Tax Reform, which was completed in 2010.1 The 
purpose of that SSTA was to identify and explore high-level policy issues, options, and future 
research  needs  associated  with  financing  ordinary  and  rural  road  construction  and 
maintenance, with the aim of improving the sustainability of ordinary roadway programs in the 
PRC. The SSTA found that, while fuel tax reform had a number of positive effects, several key 
issues need to be addressed to make the financing system for ordinary roads in the PRC 
sustainable. These issues are to be addressed in the TA as described below. 
9.  Task 1: Ensuring sufficient funding for ordinary roads. The fuel tax reform effort has 
exposed the need to increase the revenues collected and distributed to finance needed road 
maintenance, rehabilitation, and construction. The TA should adapt best practices from around 
the  world  to  the  PRC  context  to  develop  policy  proposals  to  ensure  that  sufficient  and 
sustainable revenues are available to finance ordinary road needs. Within this broad topic area 
related to the quantity of funding available, there are several distinct issues that must be 
addressed in the TA:  
(i)  Inflation. To ensure that revenues do not grow much more slowly than costs, a 
mechanism  must  be  established  to  ensure  that  the  tax  rate  is  adjusted  for 
inflation  at  regular  intervals.  Research  with  reference  to  the  PRC’s  legal 
framework for tax policy and lessons from international experience should be 
used to identify the most promising methods of adjusting the current fuel tax rate 
and address the legal framework for tax rate adjustment in the PRC. 
(ii)  New revenues. Even disregarding inflation, revenues are well below what is 
needed to maintain the road network and fund ongoing construction. To close the 
funding gap over the next 5 to 10 years, the consultants shall propose practical 
ways to increase revenues for ordinary roads from central, provincial, and local 
governments while adhering, as much as possible, to the principle of the user 
pays. The consultants shall (a) assess the feasibility of increasing the existing 
fuel tax and vehicle purchase or use tax, (b) estimate the rates that would be 
required to close the funding gap, and (c) assess the feasibility and revenue-
raising potential of development impact fees and of mobilizing private sector 
resources to address funding shortfalls. 
(iii)  Debt. There is a need to clarify the ongoing role and oversight of debt financing 
to deliver roadway projects. Research should explore ways to rationalize future 
borrowing for roadway investment with national program goals and sustainable 
practices by exploring whether standards or requirements should be established 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Financing Road Construction and 
Maintenance after Fuel Tax Reform. Manila.

Appendix 3  11 
to ensure that provincial and local governments do not become overleveraged. 
The consultants will highlight how other countries address the debt issue and 
extract any lessons that could be utilized in the PRC to support policy reform in 
this area. The consultants will provide recommendations regarding the funding 
sources  that  should  be  used  to  secure  debt  and/or  provide  debt  service 
payments, including any legal, policy, or other changes needed to facilitate this 
use.  
(iv)  Long-run feasibility. While the short-term prospects for the gas tax are strong, 
there is clearly the possibility that the transition to alternative fuel and high-
efficiency  vehicles  will  eventually  reduce  fuel  consumption  and  limit  the 
sustainability of depending on the fuel tax. Several countries have begun to 
explore  the  implementation  of  distance-based  taxes  as  a  possible  future 
replacement for fuel taxes. The PRC may wish to explore whether a distance-
based tax is a future option and, if so, consider the steps that will need to be 
taken in the next few years to facilitate a smooth transition to such a tax in the 
medium- to long-term. 
 
10.  Task  2:  Reforming  program  management  and  performance.  Centralizing  the 
collection of road charges and the allocation of road funding highlights the need to develop a 
clear and well-defined program management framework. Fuel tax reform provides the central 
government with justification and means to ensure that limited roadway resources are spent 
efficiently, effectively, and in accordance with national goals and priorities. Many countries have 
addressed these same issues in developing their road financing systems and can provide 
examples of successful approaches that could be adapted to the PRC and highlight potential 
pitfalls. The TA shall address the following key management and performance issues: 
(i)  Roles and responsibilities. The division of roles and responsibilities of each 
level of government needs to be clarified under the new centralized revenue-
collection scheme. The centralization of revenue collection and allocation has 
been accomplished, yet provincial responsibilities for planning, financing, and 
maintaining ordinary roads remain the same. The TA shall recommend changes 
to the division of roles and responsibilities at each level of government to improve 
transparency and the ability of the government to ensure adequate performance. 
(ii)  Programmatic approach. The TA will recommend whether to move toward a 
programmatic  approach,  in  which  funding  would  be  dedicated  to  specific 
purposes that could be determined according to national goals such as safety, 
maintenance, and operation, and/or to direct construction spending to certain 
categories of roadways or other types of projects. Lessons from national and 
international experience and analysis of the needs and characteristics of the 
PRC road sector will be the bases for determining appropriate categories and 
associated funding levels or shares, program management and oversight needs, 
and funding allocation methodologies.  
(iii)  Fund management and allocation. The TA will recommend whether the PRC 
should, like many countries, dedicate its transportation taxes and user fees to a 
trust fund and provide recommendations on how such a fund should be managed. 
The allocation of transportation funds generally requires some form of formula or 
rule-base allocation. The consultants will examine international experience with 
shadow tolling and assess the feasibility of using shadow tolls to finance new 
road construction and maintenance in the PRC. The consultants will, based on 
the needs of the funding allocation system and the availability and quality of 
information from provincial and local governments, recommend what data would

12  Appendix 3 
be required on key allocation factors (e.g., traffic levels, congestion, network 
condition, etc.) to effectively and efficiently manage the road funding programs.  
(iv)  Organizational capacity. The TA needs to address whether MOT and other 
central government agencies such as the Ministry of Finance have the staff 
resources and management systems required to effectively oversee and support 
a centralized roadway funding program and recommend changes to provide the 
needed capacity for program management and oversight. 
(v)  Performance management. Management systems will require that some sort of 
performance management targets be established for different elements of the 
roadway system (e.g., congestion, pavement condition, bridge condition, safety, 
etc.), program administration (e.g., administrative costs, on-time and on-budget 
delivery,  transparency  and  accountability,  etc.),  and  investment  and  subsidy 
criteria (e.g., return on investment, distributional goals, regional equity, etc.). The 
consultants  will  identify  the  key  performance  metrics  that  will  be  needed  to 
implement the policy reform recommendations and describe how the information 
should be utilized to ensure that a sustainable, equitable, and transparent road 
financing system is implemented in the PRC. 
 
11.  Task 3: Implementation plan. The TA should propose specific policy changes and 
proposals and a phased implementation strategy that MOT can use to support dialogue and 
consensus building among key government agencies with the goal of eventually presenting the 
proposals to the State Council. 
12.  Task  4:  Knowledge  products  and  services.  Additional  knowledge  products  and 
services that build on the findings of the TA will be developed to provide information to key 
policy makers in the PRC and other developing member countries. Knowledge products and 
services may include the development of a component in the knowledge-sharing platform by 
which the PRC can share its experiences of implementing a sustainable financing system for 
road construction and maintenance based on fuel taxes. 
C.  Study Approach and Methodology 
 
13.  Inception activities. For each key road financing issue, the consultants will develop a 
working paper that will be circulated prior to the inception workshop and refined after receiving 
comments from the project steering committee, MOT, and ADB. The initial working papers will 
(i) describe the issue in detail and state the rationale for policy change in that area, (ii) describe 
the  status  quo  and  the  range  of  policy  options  that  will  be  considered,  (iii)  identify  other 
countries that have chosen particular policy directions and highlight the pros and cons of each 
option, and (iv) present the methodology that will be used to analyze and select the final 
proposals, including data needs and evaluation criteria. The working papers will be incorporated 
into an inception report that will present the key findings from the SSTA, state the purpose and 
rationale for the follow-on TA, and specify the TA outputs in detail. 
14.  After the inception workshop, the working papers will be updated based on the workshop 
results and comments from MOT and ADB. The revised working papers will be submitted to the 
steering  committee  to  develop  consensus  on  the  proposed  direction  and  ensure  that  it  is 
feasible. Issues that are unlikely to be solved under the TA will be set aside for future research. 
15.  Prior to the interim report, the TA consultants will design an overseas training program 
for decision makers who will visit one or more developed countries with a financing system 
based on fuel taxes that can provide examples of the various policy options being explored

Appendix 3  13 
under the TA. The goal of the training program will be to learn lessons from international 
experience, consult with policy makers in other countries, and relate international experience 
and best practices to the situation in the PRC. 
16.  Interim activities. In the interim stage, updated working papers will be prepared to 
present the analysis conducted on each key issue, describe the experiences of similar policies 
implemented in other countries, assess the suitability of the policy options to the situation in the 
PRC, and narrow the options down to the preferred policies that will be recommended by the TA 
for each key area. The working papers will be incorporated into an interim report that clearly 
lays out the proposed policy recommendations, as well as the rationale and analyses conducted 
to support the recommendations. An interim workshop will be held to present and discuss the 
findings to date. Following the interim workshop, updated working papers will be circulated to 
the project steering committee, MOT, and ADB.  
17.  Final  report  development.  After  the  revised  interim  working  papers  have  been 
approved by the project steering committee and ADB, the TA will develop the detailed policy 
proposals for each key road financing issue. The policy proposals will take into account the 
specific needs and policy-making environment in the PRC and learn from experiences and best 
practices in other countries and the results of the overseas training program. The working 
papers will then be circulated to the steering committee, MOT, and ADB. In the event that the 
steering committee cannot come to a consensus on the proposed policy direction for one or 
more of the key policy issues regarding the road financing system, the TA will document these 
concerns, identify the additional analysis required to develop a final policy recommendation, and 
leave the issue for future research. The final report will present the specific policy proposals and 
include a proposed implementation strategy that identifies provinces where the recommended 
changes potentially can be pilot tested before scaling up the reforms countrywide.  
D.  Reporting 
 
18.  The consultants will submit (i) an inception report, 3 weeks after commencement of 
services, detailing the consultant team’s understanding of the issues to be addressed in the TA; 
the approach, methodology, and information required to complete the TA; and a series of 
working papers describing the initial thinking of the consultant team on the recommended policy 
directions; (ii) an interim report, after 24 weeks, including updated working papers on each topic, 
initial findings, and draft recommendations; (iii) a draft final report, after 36 weeks, including final 
working  papers,  key  findings,  conclusions,  policy  reform  proposals,  and  a  proposed 
implementation plan; and (iv) a final report, 2 weeks after the receipt of review comments from 
ADB and MOT. Workshops will be planned and held in the inception, interim, and final phases 
and include high-level consultation with key policy makers and other sector stakeholders. 
19.  MOT requires five copies of each report and working paper in English and Chinese, the 
Ministry of Finance (TA Division) two copies of each report in English and Chinese, and ADB 
five copies of each report in English and Chinese. The consultants will report on progress and 
key findings to the project steering committee. The team leader and the deputy team leader will 
edit the final report for publication. All reports will be submitted in both hard copy and soft copy.
